thread.title: Royals one game from World Series after beating Jays
thread.title_full: Royals one game from World Series after beating Jays

title: Royals one game from World Series after beating Jays
text:
Facebook Email Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest Royals batter Blue Jays again, pull within one game from World Series Breaking down the American League Championship Series Game 4 between the Blue Jays and Royals from Rogers Centre: Post to Facebook Royals batter Blue Jays again, pull within one game from World Series Breaking down the American League Championship Series Game 4 between the Blue Jays and Royals from Rogers Centre: Check out this story on USATODAY.com: http://usat.ly/1LJp0UW Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Join the Nation's Conversation To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Royals batter Blue Jays again, pull within one game from World Series Steve Gardner , USA TODAY Sports 7:47 p.m. EDT October 20, 2015 Ben Zobrist and Alcides Escobar celebrate after Zobrists two-run home run in the first inning. (Photo: John E. Sokolowski, USA TODAY Sports) CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
TORONTO – Breaking down the American League Championship Series Game 4 between the Blue Jays and Royals from Rogers Centre: 
Royals 14, Blue Jays 2 , Royals lead series, 3-1. 
*** 
The final: The Royals came out swinging against Jays starter R.A. Dickey from the opening pitch. Ben Zobrist hit a two-run homer as the first four Kansas City batters all scored in the first. 
Dickey recorded just five outs before being pulled from the game. Although the Blue Jays looked like they might slug their way back, Royals starter Chris Young was effective enough over 4 2/3 innings to turn a three-run lead over to his lock-down bullpen. 
Lorenzo Cain extended his postseason hitting streak to 13 games, getting on base four times and driving in three runs as the Kansas City offense never slowed down. 
*** 
State of the Series: The Royals will go for the clincher Wednesday on Toronto’s home turf with right-hander Edinson Volquez on the mound. Volquez baffled the Blue Jays bats in Game 1 in Kansas City, tossing six scoreless innings in a 5-0 victory. He had all three of his pitches working that night and was able to work out of two-on, no-out jam in the sixth after throwing 111 pitches. 
The Jays will also go back to their Game 1 starter, Marco Estrada. The veteran right-hander gave up three runs on six hits in 5 1/3 innings in the opener. At home during the regular season, Estrada was 6-4 with a 2.95 ERA in 16 games (13 of them starts). 
*** 
Game 4 pivot point: An early 5-0 lead gave Young a little wiggle room – and he used a good portion of it in the bottom of the third. A one-out single by Ryan Goins and a walk to Ben Revere brought Donaldson to the plate with a chance to get the home team back in the game. 
The white towel-waving fans at Rogers Centre finally came to life with Donaldson at the plate. He lasered a 3-2 Young fastball down the left-field line that just barely hooked foul. On the next pitch, Young threw an 83 mph slider that Donaldson lined fair into the left field corner and over the wall for a double to bring home the first Toronto run. 
After an RBI groundout from Jose Bautista made it 5-2, Young escaped the jam by retiring Edwin Encarnacion on a sizzling liner to left. 
*** Blue Jays' R.A. Dickey knocked out of Game 4 in 2nd inning 
Man of the moment: Although just about every member of the Royals contributed in some way, shortstop Alcides Escobar – as he has all series long -- was the one who ignited the offense. 
His bunt single in the first was the fourth consecutive time in which he led off the game for his team and reached base. He also reached in the second when he was hit by a pitch and drove in two runs with a pair of sacrifice flies. 
All this from a guy who hit .257/.293/.320 during the regular season. 
*** 
Needing a mulligan: Blue Jays starter R.A. Dickey was masterful over the second half of the season. After the All-Star Game, the knuckleballer was 8-1 with a 2.80 ERA. One of those wins came when he blanked the Royals for seven innings at Rogers Centre. 
Although the closed roof may or may not help the knuckler dance even more, Dickey was especially good at home. But when the Royals scored four runs on him in the opening inning, it marked the first time since May 26 that Dickey had even allowed four runs in an entire game at home. 
After using five pitchers in Game 4, the Jays could have used a lengthy outing from a pitcher who doesn’t put a whole lot of stress on his arm. Instead, they were forced to go to the bullpen in the second inning when Dickey was only able to record five outs. 
*** 
Manager's special: Ned Yost’s decision to start fly-ball pitcher Chris Young at the homer-friendly Rogers Centre in Game 4 worked out perfectly. Young pitched effectively into the fifth inning despite a fastball that topped out at 89 mph. 
Young escaped serious damage in the third inning when the Jays scored twice. And Yost went to the bullpen at the perfect time when he lifted Young after a two-out single by leadoff man Ben Revere. 
With the Royals leading 5-2, the potential tying run in the on-deck circle and the dangerous Josh Donaldson up, reliever Luke Hochevar retired the AL MVP candidate on a foul popup to end the inning. 
*** 
What you missed on TV: The Toronto Symphony Orchestra embodied a pair of qualities for which the city is known. 
First, culture. The strings, brass and percussion section members combined for a flawless performance of both the U.S. and Canadian national anthems before Game 4. 
Second, politeness. A simple online commendation of the aforementioned job resulted in a thank you from the TSO twitter account less than an hour later. It's been said before but O Canada is one great national anthem. Especially when it's played by the Toronto Symphony Orchestra. — Steve Gardner (@SteveAGardner) October 20, 2015
